name: Kepler-299
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-299 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-299 is a star with 0.9920000000000001 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.03 times its radius. It is located 3538.43 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-299 is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-299 b

Kepler-299 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 2.93 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-299.

The mass of Kepler-299 b is 1.88 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-299 b is 1.32 that of Earth. At 1.88 Earth masses, Kepler-299 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-299 c

Kepler-299 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 6.89 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-299.

The mass of Kepler-299 c is 9.93 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-299 c is 2.65 that of Earth. At 9.93 Earth masses, Kepler-299 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-299, which contains 4 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
